body: There's a special kind of pride in keeping the costs at dive-bar level on New Year's Eve, when prices quadruple at seemingly every place that has a beer tap. title: Ringing In The New On the Cheap

title: MUSIC REVIEW | MATA INTERVAL; Pop-Classical Intersections, In Tune With Any Season

body: Mary Halvorson was the picture of calm at the Greenwich Village club Le Poisson Rouge on a recent evening, slouched intently over her big hollow-body guitar. title: A Versatile Guitarist 'Sort of Based in Jazz'

body: RED AND BRICK, But Not Upright Few apartment buildings in New York City flaunt their structural defects. The Leaning Brownstone of Brooklyn is an exception. But that name, emblazoned on the awning over the front door of the four-story building at 633 Union Street, is only half right. It is not a brownstone at all, but a red-brick apartment house.
title: CITY ROOM

body: BROOKLYN produced one-fifth of the nation's beer as recently as 1960. By 1976, when Rheingold and Schaefer shuttered their Brooklyn plants, the number of local breweries dropped to zero. Now the hops are stirring in Brooklyn once again. Sixpoint Craft Ales, which has been brewing an increasingly popular range of beers in a small brew house in Red
title: Brooklyn Returns To a Heady Time

body: FROM one angle -- say, from the corner of Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street -- downtown Brooklyn might seem to be a horrible place to live. Look over one shoulder and there's the abandoned Brooklyn House of Detention, which the city has considered revitalizing as a combination jail and multiuse project. Over the other shoulder are several lanes
title: HABITATS; Finding the Best Side of a Neighborhood

author: MATT GROSS writes the Frugal Traveler column for the Travel section.
body: AT its most generous, New York bestows a rare gift upon visitor and resident alike: it makes you feel young. Stride down its granite-steel-and-glass corridors, and your viewpoint is instantly that of a child, eyes directed forever upward. But New York offers a deeper sense of youth, too, the earnest expectation that one day, out of the blue, your
title: Frugal New York

body: THOUGH New Yorkers were recently brought up short by the financial crisis, with no one quite knowing just how bad it would be, one thing this city has going for it is its resiliency. title: 36 Hours: New York City

body: To the Editor: The Gil Hodges Memorial Garden, which honors the Dodgers first baseman who went on to manage the Mets to their World Series championship in 1969, is on a small lot at Carroll Street and Denton Place in Gowanus, Brooklyn. The Dodgers played at nearby Washington Park before Ebbets Field was built. Marilyn Pettit Red Hook, Brooklyn
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Laughing Matters, Disappearing Grass and Luxe Dorms

title: LIFE AS A RUNWAY; I'll Have a Sarsaparilla, Barkeeper

title: A Festival Not to Be Taken Seriously, Unless It Is

body: ''GO one stop on the express, change for the local and get on at the back of the train.'' body: THE New York event designer David Stark transforms unexpected materials, sometimes even scraps headed for the recycling bin, into works of beauty. For a National Design Awards ceremony, he once turned shredded office paper into topiary. ''I think of each project as a big art installation that happens to be for a party or a dinner,'' he said. Mr.
title: SHOPPING WITH DAVID STARK | Made With Twine

body: THESE are the rules of restaurateurship this season: be persistent and keep it simple, or get somebody else to do the heavy lifting. Restaurant openings in New York are beginning to require the kind of planning that went into the Beijing Olympics. A few of the restaurants in this annual preview were also in the preview last year, prematurely, it
title: Even Chefs Have to Wait for a Table

title: OPENING LATER

title: City Room; Have Camera, Will Trespass, On the Brooklyn Waterfront

body: How is the water? It's a question Capt. John Lipscomb is asked all the time as he patrols the Hudson estuary for Riverkeeper, an environmental group that works to improve water quality. title: Reading the River and Its Contents, With an Eye on Its Health

title: New House, Available for Delivery, Convenient to Museum

title: Double Edge to Brooklyn's Success

title: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn

title: Judge Orders Fence Struck In Brooklyn

title: Taking Lessons, and Confidence, From a Classroom on the Water

title: THE HUNT; A Handyman's Special

title: LIVING IN KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Name From London, People From Everywhere

body: Laura Werkheiser knew she would have to make many sacrifices to live in Manhattan. Foremost among them was shopping for clothes. Anticipating, rightly, that her Manhattan digs would be cramped and her budget stretched, Ms. Werkheiser, 26, shipped 18 boxes of her clothes to her parents' house in Omaha before moving here from San Francisco. The boxes
title: Starting Salaries but New York Tastes

body: A 29-year-old man was found shot to death inside a building in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on Friday, the police said. title: Man Is Found Shot to Death in an Elevator

title: DISPATCHES; Matzo? Chopsticks? Are Locusts Next?

body: I live in Brooklyn. I moved here 14 years ago for the cheap rent. It was a little embarrassing because I was raised in Manhattan, and so I was a bit of a snob about the other boroughs. title: ESSAY; I WRITE IN BROOKLYN. GET OVER IT.

title: DITMAS PARK JOURNAL; Betting on Cuisine to Marginalize Crime

title: HABITATS; An Idiosyncratic Gem In Carroll Gardens
